148754631.review:
DDLC is peak psychological Horror.

There are no complaints I could make about this game because everything it tried to achieve was executed perfectly. It has an amazing story with perfectly crafted characters. They all have their own personalities, motives, pasts and dreams and they are all available for you to figure out and discover. The gameplay follows the usual Dating-Sim type formular with a few twists here and there. For example, at the End of every in-game day, you as the player write a poem (chose a few words from a list) and present it to the literature club. Depending on which words you used the most when writing the poem, the character that likes it the most will spend some more time with you on that day. For 100% completion you will have to do a lot of replaying and reloading but the game has an auto dialog skip that stops every time something new happens or you have to make a choice. But before we talk about completion we have to start at the beginning.

Your Story begins on a regular school morning, where you meet your old friend Sayori. She has been on the lookout for a new member in the literature club and begs you to join her. Given the circumstances of being a loser, you have no other real options and decide to go with her to your first day in the club.
And from that point, your life as a member of the literature club has begun, but don’t get to comfortable, things may not be how they are presented to you. One character especially has their eyes on you, but I won’t spoil it here, even if everyone and their mother probably knows who I am referring to. 

If you only care about the horror aspect of the game and want something to play for Halloween, DDLC has a free version on steam too. The paid version is much more user-friendly and has some side content like Soundtrack list, Sidestories etc. so Its definitely worth your money if you feel invested in the story and characters.
Doki Doki literature club is an absolute masterpiece of its genre and has been highly influential when it comes to indie gaming.

I will admit i picked this up Purely For nostalgia of the game, When i was younger i watched full play throughs of it without giving it much thought, Because Of this, I already knew the plot and a vast majority of the scares, However In Spite Of this I would still consider Myself Genuinely Stunned by My play through, Even though I knew Everything that would happen the games ambiance and storytelling still managed to enthrall me and genuine terrify me At multiple points Alongside this the addition of the virtual desktop (Which is one of several new features added this in newer version) And the content contained within it made me genuinely decide to discover the games various secrets and solve the puzzles within, i was motivated to complete the game 100% Purely By its genius storytelling and atmosphere and my desire to see every small section of it,

And yet alongside the main games horror experience making me Quake with Fear, The game also drove me to literal tears multiple times through the separate side stories and how they explore the relationships between of the Characters and the immaculate writing that to me shows a genuine love the writers had for the characters they had crafted.

Doki Doki Literature club was Once to me a Good one off horror That i Bought purely to have the experience of playing it myself, But in playing it has Genuinely touched me in a way that not a lot of games have.

Thank you Team salvato and serenity forge for this incredible experience

tras platinar el juego, es hora de desarrollar una reseña constructiva del doki doki plus.
antes de comenzar la reseña voy a ir directamente a lo importante, y es que si. es un juego que recomiendo

empezando ahora si, vamos de la parte menos fuerte a la mejor del juego, ya que realmente no tengo criticas negativas para el doki.

es un juego largo, y sacar todos los logros se te va a hacer un dolor de cabeza por momentos... tiene muchas cosas ocultas, decisiones especificas y archivos que se desbloquean de formas especificas
por lo que si no tenes la intensión de conseguir todo, te recomiendo disfrutar la historia tranquilo y sin prisa.
el apartado visual del juego es bueno, suficiente. no tiene los mejores dibujos, o el mejor estilo, pero es disfrutable y tiene un buen trabajo artistico detras
y hablando del trabajo artistico, la musica de este juego es muy buena y envolvente, te da tranquilidad, felicidad o algo de tension en los momentos en que todo se descontrola.
pero mas que nada, lo que mas destaca es la historia y la forma en el que se maneja, el miedo que puede generar en momentos, pero la profundidad y la enseñanza que deja respecto a todo lo que envuelve a la poesia y la literatura (mas que nada en las historias paralelas, que hacen que valga la pena comprar el plus)
ademas de que el ddlc plus trae todo el apartado de imagenes desbloqueables, que si te lo queres platinar te va a mantener agarrado a la silla tratando de pensar formas de desbloquear los logros.

en resumidas cuentas, es un juego para tener paciencia y hacer cualquier cosa, ya que muchas acciones terminan desbloqueando archivos ocultos
buena historia, innovadora, en el que también podes comprender un poco como se manifiestan diferentes personas y ser mas atento con el entorno que te rodea, e incluso podes sentirte identificado con alguno de los personajes. un buen apartado artístico. me gusto y yo lo dejo en un 10/10. de los mejores juegos en su categoría.

144703507.review:
The review below will not contain any story-related spoilers for the game! It is directed to veterans of the original that consider to buy this new version of the game as well as to newcomers who are interested in playing for the first time.

I do encourage everyone to treat the disclaimers of Doki Doki Literature Club and its Plus version seriously. It's a game that, when effective, can absolutely be torturous to handle, especially when you're suffering from mental problems or are on the more emotional side of folks. The game has a disclaimer function that does warn you of such contents and also features a list at the beginning, should you want to prepare.

Doki Doki Literature Club Plus is not only a great way to re-experience the original game of 2017. Instead it once again subverts expectations by building upon this legacy and tells new stories that old veterans of the Literature Club as well as newcomers may enjoy. 

Many may argue that a free game of roughly six years of age didn't exactly need a new version. In fact, the original to this very day has an astounding modding scene that manages to expand a five to eight hour long visual novel into hundreds over hundreds of hours of playtime. 

However, by releasing this new version of the game, not only does the beloved Literature Club write its way into the hearts of console gamers yet intrigues veterans with added side story content that builds upon the esablished world while teasing a successor that has been eagerly awaited for quite a while by now.

As a Visual Novel, Doki Doki Literature Club Plus (or DDLC+ as I will know refer to it) you can't exactly expect any "real" gameplay from this game. While for many this may be a major downside, I can only recommend to give it a shot regardless. Not once does Doki Doki Literature Club use unnecessary padding to its story and respects its players time. Beyond that I'd argue that by what it tries to accomplish the Visual Novel was the perfect medium to use as a way to immerse the player while still creating an interactive experience, which movies and even books could not have conveyed in this specific manner.

DDLC+ as well as the original are games that absolutely want you to experience them with as little knowledge as possible, so they can fully immerse you with their stellar soundtrack, deep characters and cleverly layed-out twists. Although the four girls may come of as cliche in the beginning, I can only advise newcomers to keep pushing forward so they come to fully understand why I am so strongly praising the complextiy of them. With six side stories to also collect, there is now even more depth to the girls, which have just about the right length to not undermine the main game and still make it a worthwhile puchase for old players.

With the use of the word collect, there are now galleries and soundtracks that can be harvested by simply playing the game or fulfilling certain requirements, some of which are based on luck, which can potentially be frustrating for those who seek a 100 percent archive. However these luck based collections are few and usually not absourdly unlikely. (The lowest chance for one of the gallery entries was 1:64 if I remember correctly, the second to that is a one to eleven chance that garantues one new entry per run, so as you see while it may be low these aren't anywhere near impossible)

As someone who invests a lot of time into immersing myself into such stories I easily reached up to 30 hours to get 100 percent completion. It is likely though that people can reach this feat with half of the time spent, so take that as you will.

The game memorizes dialogue that has been read once, so there is not once a moment where players can't quickly skim through DDLC+ to experience alternative dialogue, that may derive from the player's choices. DDLC+ knows how to combine all of the points I mentioned above (characters, soundtrack, interactive elements) to subtlely build up a connection to you that I'd bet to even surprise the more unreceptive individuals.

With all that, I do recommend to purchase this version, simply for the reason that one should support people such as Dan Salvato and his team that try new things to create immersive and memorable experiences. I still have my Yuri Plushie sitting next to me which reminds me of how one man has a better understanding of how to make me feel something than multi-million-dollar companies who sacrficed that aspect of gaming to simply create "spectacular" games, who often fall flat. 

This game was the ultimate example of how to create a unique experience and judging by the size of its community, I'd argue I am not the only one to think this way.

Thank you Team Salvato and Serenity Forge for creating this worthwhile expansion to DDLC 
Thank you for the community who to this day creates equally unique content and deserves high praise as well
And thank you, reader, for taking this time to listen to my thoughts on this game!

Stay healthy and take care!

Publisher: [url=https://store.steampowered.com/publisher/serenityforge] Serenity Forge [/url]

It seemed more like a cute, innocent visual novel than a psychological horror experience.

The game starts out harmless, but after a certain point something happens that changes everything. I don't want to go into too much detail here so as not to give away spoilers, but I can say that the game played brilliantly with my expectations and completely surprised me. The psychological horror set in and I actually found myself scared during a few scenes, which is quite an achievement for a visual novel.

The game change was really masterfully executed and added even more horror to the story. The creators managed to create a dark and eerie atmosphere that pulled me deep into the action and kept me playing despite the occasional goosebumps and scares.

I found the ending particularly impressive as it touched me emotionally. When a very specific person started singing, I felt a mixture of sadness and admiration for the art of the game. It added an extra layer of depth to the already great experience and made it a memorable ending.

[b] Just Monika <3 [/b] - a sentence that took on a whole new meaning after playing and stuck in my memory. Doki-Doki Literature Club Plus is a true must-see for anyone looking for a deep and unpredictable psychological horror game. The characters, the story, the music and the twists will pull you in and won't let go.

In conclusion, I would like to say that this game exceeded my expectations and I recommend it to anyone looking for a unique and intense gaming experience.

144306065.review:
[h1] This game is not a horror game [/h1]

   Among the numerous VNs and gal games I've encountered, Team Salvato's DDLC undeniably provided me with the most captivating gameplay experience. The game is replete with intriguing in-game elements that warrant contemplation.
To commence, it's apparent without much effort that each female character possesses distinct flaws. This imparts a sense of realism to players, who subconsciously acknowledge the imperfections, thereby rendering each character more alluring and relatable. In essence, these imperfections in their personalities— [spoiler] such as Sayori's battle with depression, Natsuki's vulnerability due to domestic violence, Yuri's struggles with obsessive-compulsive disorder, and Monika's profound loneliness stemming from her realization that she can never transcend into the MC's reality [/spoiler] —are pivotal in shaping the girls into fully fleshed-out characters.

   This game diverges from the commonplace and clichéd dialogues that often permeate other PG18 gal games. In fact, the lore itself extends beyond mere interest; each line of the script holds significance and is inherently self-explanatory. This stands in stark contrast to perfunctory exchanges, often seen between friends with benefits, which tend to culminate in a merely lascivious conclusion to the narrative. Moreover, the inclusion of exquisite poems further enriches the experience, many of which serve as foreshadowing for impending events. These verses delve into the unsettling emotions that the girls grapple with when distanced from school, particularly from the MC. The backdrop of music also plays a pivotal role in enhancing both the conversations and the overall gaming experience, even in the absence of elaborate animations. Take, for instance, the theme music dedicated to the girls—'Okay Everyone!' This composition readily exhibits the interplay of cello notes in the Yuri and Sayori adaptations. The cello's use by composers to convey sorrowful or mournful moments is apparent, implying the latent melancholy within the girls' emotions that ultimately manifests in their [spoiler] tragic suicide attempts [/spoiler].

   Upon reflecting on the gaming experience, I've come to realize the abundance of heart-wrenching moments that merit acknowledgment. [spoiler] Foremost among these are the poignant scenes involving the two deceased girls. Sayori, a radiant presence, initially presents her customary cheerful facade at the story's outset. She shares with the MC, "I love happiness the most, but sometimes when you have a little rain cloud in your head... a sad poem can help embrace the rain cloud... And create a beautiful, happy rainbow!" However, towards the conclusion of the initial narrative arc, she tearfully confesses to the player, even after receiving the MC's heartfelt declaration: "Even now... Why do the rain clouds persist? They refuse to dissipate at all..." Tragically, she hangs herself the very next day. [/spoiler]

   Conversely, we encounter Yuri.  [spoiler] Despite her outward appearance of maturity and composure within the club, she undergoes a gradual transformation from rationality to mild irrationality, culminating in complete madness as the MC's affection towards her increases. Ultimately, she confesses her feelings to the MC and  in a brutal act inflicts three fatal stabs upon herself. Yuri's consciousness only resurfaces as blood pools begin to gather around her prone form on the floor, her amethyst eyes radiating an aura of regret into the void, a poignant reminder of an irreparable choice. [/spoiler]

[h1] Who's to blame? [/h1]

 [spoiler]   Many attribute the blame to Monika for her manipulation of the thoughts and consciousness of the other three girls. Yet, upon delving into the game with a fourth playthrough, a question inevitably nags at me: is Monika genuinely accountable for this intricate situation? Upon closer inspection, I can't help but question whether Monika shoulders the entire responsibility. After all, every girl holds the potential to assume the role of the literature club president. Upon deeper reflection, it becomes apparent that the true antagonist might be the player themselves, lurking behind the scenes. When one ponders this scenario, the intricate layers unravel. [/spoiler]

   The various side stories meticulously weave together a tapestry that portrays a comprehensive tableau: each of the four girls candidly unveils their vulnerabilities and imperfections, fostering a nurturing atmosphere where they support each other. This dynamic culminates in the establishment of the literature club, embodying a genuine camaraderie. However, with the entrance of the MC, the idyllic and cohesive picture disintegrates into disarray, and the virtues that once flourished crumble into oblivion.

  Thankfully, as players, we retain the power to halt this descent into chaos. [spoiler] We possess the opportunity to save Monika from her tragic fate, avert the callous act of erasing her from the game, and instead, modding the game to offer her the affection she rightfully deserves. [/spoiler] In doing so, we can rekindle and nurture at least one iridescent remnant from the good ol’ times of sunshine and rainbows, fostering a ray of hope amid the prevailing darkness.

   Finally, a round of applause to Mr. Salvato and his team for bringing us the best visual novel of the decade, keep up the good work and hopefully surprise us again with something even more spectacular in the near future.

143620670.review:
Wow, where do I even start with Doki Doki Literature Club? This game took me on a ride that I'll never forget – a journey that was equal parts heartwarming and spine-tingling, leaving me utterly captivated from start to finish.

As I stepped into the world of the literature club, I never could've anticipated the emotional rollercoaster that awaited me. The characters – Sayori, Natsuki, Yuri, and Monika – felt so real, like friends I've known for ages. That's what made the twists and turns of the narrative hit so hard. The way the story seamlessly transitioned from lighthearted banter to moments of eerie unease kept me on the edge of my seat.

And speaking of Monika, she's a character unlike any I've encountered in a game before. Her subtle presence and the way she interacts with both the story and the player left me genuinely questioning the boundaries of the digital world. It's as if she's whispering secrets in your ear, guiding you through a narrative maze that you can't help but get lost in.

The direction of the game is simply masterful. It guides you through the emotional beats of the story with such precision that you can't help but become emotionally invested. The score adds another layer to the experience, evoking emotions that range from joy to discomfort.

Visually, the game's simplistic style belies its impact. The characters' expressions, their mannerisms – they're all so well-crafted that you can't help but feel a connection. And while there aren't flashy effects, the game's subtle touches hit you in unexpected ways.

But what truly amazed me was how Doki Doki Literature Club played with my emotions. It took me from laughter to unease, from friendship to existential contemplation, all within the blink of an eye. It's this ability to toy with your feelings that makes the game an absolute masterpiece.

Sure, there are moments when the narrative's tone shifts abruptly, almost disorienting you. But here's the thing – it's deliberate. It adds a layer of complexity that challenges your perception, making you question the very essence of storytelling.

In the end, Doki Doki Literature Club isn't just a game; it's an experience that stays with you long after you've put down the controller. The emotions it evokes, the questions it raises – they all become a part of you. If you're ready for a narrative journey that defies conventions, that lingers in your mind, and that makes you question the very nature of reality, then this game is an absolute must-play.

143085899.review:
If you've played the original and wonder if this is worth buying, let me just tell you yes it is. Is the original story changed? No. Is there enough side stories that were not in the original to make it worth buying? Absolutely. There's enough extra content in addition to the side stories that makes it worth buying. The virtual machine concept they added to it also made it more fun. If you're a fan of the original game that was given to us absolutely free, then pay for this cheap 15 dollar product. It is worth the price, trust me. I never bought any fan items online, have always enjoyed this masterpiece without paying a dime, and decided this was worth a try and it ended up being 100% worth it.

My only criticism: There's a couple achievements that rely on RNG drops, which I cannot stress how much I absolutely despise, but I endured them bc I love this game. If that's something that you have no desire to endure, then you can skip them as they're 100% optional and don't offer anything significant as far as storyline. It didn't take me long to get them, but I just despise those concepts. That's really the only negative thing I can say about this game (and maybe that's more Steam than Team Salvato?).

I also wanted to add that I liked how you could turn off those trigger warnings. Having been through panic attacks, depression, sucide attempts and PTSD myself, I can say with full confidence the only thing that helped me feel like I gained back my sanity and control of my life is to face my fears head-on, and trigger warnings never benefited me whatsoever. There's studies that support trigger warnings are not effective and can even make things worse. With that being said, I know everyone is different, and facing my fears head-on only worked for me because I was the one that decided to pull the cord. If you're not ready and you need those trigger warnings, no judgment to you, but I just encourage you to make it a goal to work towards facing your fears head-on and to eventually remove the need for trigger warnings, and to make that decision yourself and not expect someone to force you into it. You will feel much more powerful and confident when you find the courage within yourself to face those fears. You can do it just like I did, I believe in you. You will know when the time is right for you. Believe in yourself. And I wanted to add I respect Team Salvato and Serenity Forge for giving the option to turn those on or off. Having the option to turn them off is just as important, if not more, than having the option to turn them on.

I also wanted to add I love the new artwork that was not in the original. I love the new character artwork (photos, graphics), new side stories, new music. I especially loved some of the songs that were new but incorporated parts of the old songs into it. Nice bit of a remix, if you will. I remember being perfectly content one day just listening to the new music and scrolling through the artwork, without even playing the game, and I'm sure I'll have more days like that. It amazes me how much effort was put into such an affordable game, and that's why I've always respected Team Salvato.

If you're reading comments to see if it's worth buying, BUY IT!!! It's not that expensive anyways, just do it. You know you'll love it if you already played the original. If you're new to it, I'm telling you, you're in for a real treat.

142249573.review:
Doki Doki Literature Club Plus! (DDLCP!) expands on the original game with additional content, new side stories, and a physical collector's edition. For newcomers, it offers a chilling visual novel experience where your choices matter. The game introduces six side stories that provide insights into the characters' backgrounds. Replayability is encouraged to unlock missed content and explore the game's operating system.

 The new stories, while short, offer a deeper perspective and come with additional music and artwork. The expansion adds 13 new music tracks and over 100 pieces of artwork, expanding the DDLC! universe. DDLCP! is a great addition for fans, offering new secrets to discover. However, players familiar with DDLC! may not experience the same level of surprise of those coming in blind. Overall, it's a worthwhile experience for both new and returning players, but be aware... 

[b] This game is not suitable for children or those who are easily disturbed. [/b]

141791977.review:
Just move your hand, write your way into his heart...

This game works like a visual novel, there's nothing much to say about its mechanics, the focus here is the writing.
For people, who like me, doesn't had any kind of contact with DDLC before. this game's first act can be a bit deceitful, baiting the player to think that this is your average dating sim game, four cute heroines for you to win their affection through a word selection system that supposedly, will be your way to unlock their routes and move on in the story... well, it is, until you gently open the door and the second act starts.
DDLC has an interesting concept that is very well executed, giving us an endearing plot and lovely characters to enjoy through the game. 

As an extra, you can also play the side stories. These are tales centered on the beginning of the club and how the characters joined it. We gain a lot more depth in the characters as we can see how they deal with their struggles and insecurities as they start to build their relationships and begin to shape the literature club together. 
There's some great writing here with beautiful messages.

the OSTs are beautiful and settles the tone of the scenes perfectly. 

I truly recommend this game.

141734265.review:
I didn't think they could make the game any better, but they did. Imma dissect this real good for you. As for the base game itself, unfortunately they changed pretty much nothing. The art is exactly the same just with a slightly higher quality, and the only real changes are slight dialogue edits (For example, the line at the end of the game where Monika mentions how she spoke to you on the game's steam page is no longer there as that is not the case for DDLC+). These dialogue edits are very subtle and you're likely to not notice them at all. The real bulk of the new content and the only real reason to buy this game is the side stories. I personally find them quite entertaining and heartwarming although i recommend experiencing them after finishing the main story, as stopping to watch the heartwarming story of the group member meeting each other then transitioning back to seeing them commit self harm is, as you can imagine, quite jarring. Also, there are actually 7 side stories, not six, a special one is unlocked for completing the other 6. Also also, the game is now run from a virtual desktop, which isn't really a positive or a negative tbh. I think they could've made the game even better by finding a way to implement the stories into the base game itself and helping it flow along with the rest of the story. There was no need to preserve the original experience imo especially considering that the original is free to experience for everyone. Overall its like a strong 8.8 or 9.0 out of 10. 140817407.review:
If you're here, you've probably already played the original and you heard there's a version of the game with a price now for some reason. Is it worth the price? The answer is: Yes.

Horror-wise there's nothing new, but that's only cuz they already perfected it, so there's no more needed. There are however prequel side-stories where you learn a lot more about the friendships between all the girls, as well as behind the scenes of this "game". There are also achievements which I got all of after 18 hours and a customizable in-game desktop (so console player can access the game files). Select your wallpaper and music! Even tho this is a horror game, there's still a really wholesome side to it, which this game really worked on.

If you only liked the game because of its horror, then perhaps this isn't for you. But if you had any enjoyment learning about the characters, you should definitely buy this game.

If you haven't played the original for some reason, play it first (it's free!). Then judging by what I've told you, you can consider buying this game too.

I've never really written a proper review for a game before but I had so much fun with this one I felt like I needed to write my thoughts on it a bit. All the new content is really cool but I have to say that the side stories alone makes the game worth buying. 
 I liked having the virtual desktop as it felt like it fit more with the game rather than going into your actual files (and made it easier when I was recording my playthrough), plus having that affects the new lore added to the game. The lore itself, shown through "emails" I'm a little iffy on but everything else was really cool.  

Getting 100% (both within the game and on Steam) definitely took some time and could be a little annoying. Not anything too difficult but there was a few things where I didn't know what I was missing so I had to look up a guide.  Some secrets and things have a 1/whatever chance of appearing so those can take a while to randomly show up and to get the steam achievements at least, you'll have to do multiple playthroughs. Luckily after your second playthrough you would have seen all the dialouge already so the game goes super fast as you can just skip everything and click through the poems. That makes it easier if you need to be in a specfic spot in the game or are trying to do multiple routes in one playthrough. Though it took me 18 hrs to 100% everything, i'd say a lot of the time was just from replaying the game or taking my time reading all the dialogue in the side stories, so if you're not trying to do everything in the game, then you'll get through it really fast.

140542493.review: okay, there is a lot to unpack here. (all good, ofc.) DDLC is an amazing game. But that's just in short. I've played the OG game without the extras about each character, and it's one of the few games I can go back and play over and over again. The writing is incredible, each of the girls has their each unique personalities and interests, and the psychological horror aspect still freaks me out to this day. Yes it has very cute, wholesome moments and a lot of scary aspects, but it also has a deeper meaning and dives into the struggles of mental health. Yes, the mental health aspects are taken to an extreme in this game, but there's really good moments about caring for each other, and the values of friendship. Each of the girls have a unique relationship with one another and that is truly special, and you can clearly see it in the OG game. Now for the added on extras of each character, they are sad enough to make a grown man cry. There's nothing scary, nothing hiding in your files to scare you, and no love interests. Just pure love and care from each of the girls to one another and their stories. Truly an amazing game and if you love the OG DDLC, appreciate the characters, then DDLC plus is for you.

140034953.review:
Honestly, it's like 99% similar to the main game.

One of the main differences is there's a virtual desktop now. That virtual desktop is where everything in the game is kept, including actually starting the game. There's also the folders with all the .chr files and other miscellaneous things.
While I think the concept is cool, there's some flaws, and here's why I think that. (Contains spoilers)

If a brand new player buys this game and has never exposed themselves to DDLC ever, the virtual desktop will make it easier for them to find all the secret files. And even then, there's no hints that there's secret files in the first place. The player will have to randomly click on the folder on the virtual desktop to find them. 
Sure, it did make it easier for new players to find them, since the player will never think to look in the game files until act 3 when Monika tells them about the files in there.

Speaking of act 3, it's more or less the same. However, Monika tells you about how the files are in a really easily accessible folder. In the first game, she tells you how to get to them by going to the game files. So in the end, it wouldn't have made a difference.

Act 1 and 2 are also more or less the same.

So my final verdict is: There's really no reason to buy this game. It's almost identical to the original (free) one. If you saw the banner and thought the game would have improved graphics, well, no, the in game graphics weren't changed either.

(Sorry if my review isn't very good, I don't write them very often)

138302921.review: There are so many reasons this game is special and I highly recommend not reading or watching anything to fully experience all of its features. 138301474.review: If this game were a food, it would be a delicious blooming onion, fried golden brown but with a spot of rot at it's center. So many overlapping layers of complexity that 'meta' doesn't go far enough to explain the mind-trip it takes you on. And just when you think you've found the final layer, BOOM, more layers. As delightful as it is disturbing and unexpected. NOT for younger players or those who are easily upset by heavy topics. Go in blind and just play through once as you normally would and then look for help on the more hidden aspects of the game later if you need them. The only part I disliked was the RNG (random, low-probability events) needed to reach 100% completion, but even they weren't too terrible. A solid 9/10 for me. My only question is, when do we get the next installment...? My Third Eye is eager for more.

137985151.review: As much as I loved playing the original game, coming back and revisiting the story and secrets under the goal of achieving 100% Data Collected and getting all pictures was a beautiful experience. Every amazing thing that applied to the original game still applies to Plus, but just with a slew of new content and refinements. I don't think I could say the side stories were perfect, but that's largely just because comparing them to the original game is such a high bar it's difficult to surpass it, and I still very much enjoyed my play-through. The new pictures, promos, sketches, and secrets were all very much appreciated and made for a great experience. All around, Doki Doki Literature Club as a whole has cemented it's place at least for me as one of my favorite games of all time, it's one of the most creative titles I've ever seen and executes its message to such an extent to actually leave a resounding impact on the player, something few games can manage to do. 10/10, would absolutely recommend playing.

137903589.review:
I’ve played a quite a few games over the years, some great, some not, but there are a select few that for me have really scratched that itch, that leave me feeling really glad I played it. This is one of those games, a deceptively innocent façade, a seemingly simple before seen concept, and then before you know it, drops the act to really sell one hell of a unique narrative.

Doki Doki Literature Club is deceptive in its storytelling, and for someone like me who loves a good story full mystery and secrets, it was right up my alley. Yet it was the way in which it presented this narrative that grappled my interest. The front of a seemingly innocent visual novel of romance was as far removed from its true intentions as it could have ever been, but it is the contrast between its disguise and actuality that make it work so well.

The storytelling was only further fuelled by the meticulousness of the dialogue, the tone setting of the music or lack thereof in cases, and of course the beautiful artwork that didn’t hold back even when things got graphic.

Beyond its artistry, there isn’t much else to it, game play mechanics are simple and the running time isn’t tens of hours, but that’s a good thing. It gives its focus where it needs to, it paces itself to hit all the right notes at all the right times. You can tell time and effort went into making it what it was, because there is no filler, there is no deviating from the main path, it is true to what it wants to be, and that is what makes it work so well.

On a final note then, Doki Doki Literature Club is a diamond among coals, a small narrative journey that questions the morals, that leads you unknowingly into more than you came for. I can honestly say I enjoyed my time with it and I would give anything to have something like it again.

Entré a jugar este juego sin saber mucho de él, solo que era un juego de terror pese al tono "adorable'' que presenta en un comienzo. Pese a todo, no es un juego perfecto, personalmente, creo algunos diálogos son un poco pesados, pero nada que mate la experiencia. Tampoco es que haya un tremendo desarrollo en la historia o en los personajes, el juego no busca eso, tiene su propia forma de contarte las cosas, y toca temas oscuros e interesantes que vale la pena analizar.

Por último, recomendaría a quienes lo jueguen que [b]no busquen nada por internet [/b], no miren guías ni nada, no piensen en buscar un final perfecto o seguir una ruta de forma perfecta; créanme, solo disfruten de la experiencia, porque eso es lo más valioso en este juego. Doki Doki Literature Club Plus! is a game that will make you laugh, cry, and question your sanity. 

You play as a high school student who joins a literature club with four cute girls. Sounds fun, right? Well, not exactly. As you get to know them better, you discover that they have some dark secrets and twisted personalities. And they are all obsessed with you. 

Doki Doki Literature Club Plus! is not for the faint of heart. It is a psychological horror game that will mess with your mind and break your heart. But hey, at least you get to write some poems along the way.

135708179.review: I haven't played any visual novels prior to DDLC Plus, and I'm definitely not someone who plays dating sims. I am, however, a big fan of games with a deep story. The narrative quality and the ride that this game takes you on is up there with the best games I've ever played. The characters may at first seem like tropes or archetypes, but the further you get into the game the more it becomes clear that they are much more than that. Combine that with the additional backstory you can learn about as you play through the game and this truly is one of the more engaging games I've played. It may not be everyone's cup of tea, but in my opinion this one is worth checking out.

135670180.review:
[h1][b]Doki Doki Literature Club[/b][/h1]
[b]Where to even start? [strike]Most likely nobody or at the very least few people are going to read this[/strike] but I felt inclined to write something for this masterpiece of a game. This won't even be a review, this game means a lot to me and lots of other people and it felt wrong not to write some kind of love letter or anything at all, so here goes...
Starting of a list of what makes DDLC, in my eyes, one of the best story driven games ever created:[/b]
Cleverly deceiving game design; Perfect psychological horror experience; Realistic depiction of people's hardships and mental issues (DDLC+ especially); Purposefully 'cringy' designed characters using typical anime tropes, to made them seem like typical Dating Sim girls (og DDLC), yet with the introduction with DDLC+ they became something much more; REALLY catchy and memorable soundtrack with repeating leitmotif, that makes you want to bust a move, and depending on the context can be either happy or unsettling (og DDLC); One of the best soundtracks in the video game I've ever heard (DDLC+); Cute girls ;Actually good poetry and writing advices, that makes you want to write something yourself or at least pick up a book to read; [spoiler]4th wall breaking, making YOU the part of the game's story, and which for example, takes advantage of how the game behaves when certain files are missing; (Along with Undertale/Deltarune) One of the most interesting Lore, that still keeps me invested in the game today, told mostly through game files and unlockable in-game emails. Despite game being popular, not many people know how deep this game is. (Mention what 'Metaverse Enterprise Solutions' or 'VM1/VM2' is to avarage DDLC fan and they'll think you're crazy); Game's story take's place in multiple universes and timelines; Light time travel themes; Monika's character is genius (More on her bellow); Monika's Act III dialogue - she's suprisingly smart with a lot of quaity life advices.[/spoiler] Room for fan interpretations of the game - that's where Modding Community comes in. There's a lot of high quality mods that either expand the original game concept or turn the game 180 degrees telling completely different story with familiar faces.

[b][i]*BIG SPOILERS* Few words about Monika's character and her story, an analysis if you will:[/i][/b]
Monika (in the main game) is a regular high school girl with the for literature, who one day got access to knowledge and abilities that no human should ever possess, knowledge that would traumatize many or even made someone take their life. An ability to see past the artificial reality and change the world around her to her own will. Yet, although not exactly sane, she stands tall, smiling, holding onto her hopes that one day perhaps she will leave this prison or at the very least get a taste of the world outside of her reach, making her really admirable character. Cannonically DDLC universe, originally was never supposed to be a game, at first it was a only a simulated universe created(?) by company called 'Metaverse Enterprise Soulutions' that was ment to be used for gathering data and ovserving behavior of the human-like entities inside. Said company is also responsible for Monika's powers (Elevated Access, is what they call it), they gave her those powers in order to observe how a person might behave to an exposure of such knowledge, as well as trying to find clues and patterns present in both simulated and real world to try find proof that OUR universe is also simulated.
With that out of the way - In order for Monika to get a glimpse of our world, she had to manufacture a way for us to interact with her world. That's how MC, the character we play as was created, or at least Monika's meddling with the code made him join the Literature Club. That is when MES decided to disguise their simulation under the cover of a 'video game'. Throughout the early part of the game, Monika is trying to keep her composure in check, trying to be 'normal' yet desirable to the player, without making any sudden moves, but also not making [i]no[/i] moves at all, each day she gives the player slight hints of the person she is behind the mask, through her 'abstract' poetry. At the same time, she gradually increases Sayori's depression and later in the game as she get's more and more desperate and impatient, Yuri's obsessive traits as well as Natsuki's terrible home life, everything by changing their code to make them 'less desireble' and prevent them from confessing, unfortunately that doesn't go exactly as planned cause they end up confessing anyway, after all, she's just a high school girl with no experience in coding, trying to make changes, not a computer expert. But there are also few more mistakes Monika makes, first being on a moral level - her reasoning states that 'if nothing is real, then it's ok to kill and whatnot'. Monika clearly haven't thought that through, her desperation really shows, she's forgetting that she is as real as them, she is a part of this world. For us players, killing video game characters is nothing crazy, we do that all the time without giving it much thought, but Monika's case isn't so black and white, when the world around you, fake or not, is the place you were born, is your home, is the place were you made friends, killing people, literary is the equivalent of US murdering someone irl (but in her defense, I wonder how would YOU behave if you were in her place). She also believes that 'her friends don't have free will, they're just lines of code', half of the statement is in fact true, but she overlooked the fact that along with the changes she makes, Natsuki for example, reacts accordingly to the situation, her letter to MC about how she's worried about Yuri, doesn't exactly seemed like something Monika planned, rather it is something that Natsuki willingly wrote. That's not exactly reading script, is it Monika? Based on that fact, for me it makes the characters much more like an AI rather than mindless NPCs chained to their script (which they technically and cannonically are). Since she can change almost anything, wouldn't a smarter option be to either try completely change their personality to something that would keep her sane, to have some company or at least try to explain her bizzare situation to other girls and support one another? Imagine an ending in the style of Act III like that, where every girl is aware of players presence, and you can visit them from time to time by opening the game and talk to them idividualy as they live their lifes with their newfound knowledge. Don't mind me, I'm just fantasizing.
Anyway, her another mistake ties to the last one - As her original plan of pursuing the player failed, due to the game not letting us chose her, Monika getting impatient is willing to sacrifice the whole world, risking accidentally deleting herself for something that has no guarantee of working out, have she even taken into consideration how the person on the other side might feel about her plan? For a player, she's still only a video game character, they might have just wanted to play regular dating sim, but at the end were forced to play by her rules. That is not what someone on the right mind does - erasing everything from existance, but an empty room you plan to sit in till the end of time, with a person whom you'll likely never even see (...)

Bruh, I had to delete a big chunk of this, because it was too long. So I guess that concudes this 'review', I don't even know how to end this long ass elaboration, since steam left it hanging. [i]It won't be finnished, it will just stop moving.[/i] But I just want to finnaly post it.
*CONTINUATION IN THE COMMENTS*

[i]Thank you Dan for this unforgettable experience![/i]

Doki Doki Literature Club Plus! is basically a DLC to the original DDLC. However, I would recommend purchasing this after testing the OG and seeing if you want this or not. This paid version doesn't have the themes that the main story has and mostly focuses on the girls and their relationship between each other before the MC (you) are introduced to them. 135515153.review:
With this plus version, you get [u]new features[/u] + side stories along with the original content of Doki Doki Literature Club. Each girl is incredibly unique, with their own stories to tell. Each decision you make in the game is vital. There are three different endings you can get. You can [u]experience the relationship between the four girls with the new side stories[/u] available to you in this version. 
This game has made me feel fear more than any other horror game has. The cute appearance of this game is deceiving, putting you in comfort and then slowly making you feel the essence of its hidden genre. The story does not take long to complete, although it took me about ~45 hours to reach full completion, perhaps with some procrastination. Just keep in mind that there is an RNG-based achievement.
As amazingly terrifying as this game is, I would [u]only recommend buying it if you're a fan[/u]. All the newly added things: [i]CGs, music player, mail messages[/i], and of course, the side stories, perhaps wouldn't appeal to regular players. So, I would only recommend buying this if you're a fan. I don't believe there is anything that I can criticize about this game. It is perfect for me. Be sure to [b][u]play the original game first before deciding on whether to buy this or not[/u][/b].

135195649.review:
Doki Doki Literature Club is a truly unique game that defies expectations and challenges the traditional visual novel genre. At first glance, it may seem like a typical dating sim, but it quickly becomes apparent that there's much more going on beneath the surface.

The game takes you on a rollercoaster ride of emotions, with unexpected twists and turns that keep you on the edge of your seat. The characters are well-written and engaging, and their stories are compelling and heart-wrenching.

What sets Doki Doki Literature Club apart from other visual novels is its use of metafiction and psychological horror elements. It's a game that messes with your head and makes you question your own perceptions of reality. The fourth-wall breaking moments are especially effective in creating a sense of unease and discomfort.

Despite its dark themes, Doki Doki Literature Club also has moments of warmth and genuine emotion. The friendship and romance between the characters are touching and heartwarming, and the game's soundtrack is beautiful and haunting.

Overall, Doki Doki Literature Club is a must-play for anyone who enjoys visual novels or psychological horror games. It's a game that will stay with you long after you've finished it, and one that you'll want to replay again and again to uncover all of its secrets. Highly recommended.

135067304.review:
I read an Amazon review for this game that states: "Yuri is the best donkey in the Donkey Donkey club". I still think about it often.

Anyway, I have mixed feeling about the main game, but bought this for the side stories. They didn't disappoint. The creepypasta aspects are dropped for a series of quiet, sympathetic tales that treat the cast--and their insecurities/illnesses--with discretion and empathy, away from the dating-sim harem nonsense and overt fourth-wall destruction (Note: I do acknowledge both of these things were imperative to the original narrative's purpose. Even so, I stand by the point). It felt like closure, labelled seperate from the main story and only being unlocked after it--even though they're collectively considered a "prequel" or "alternate timeline" of sorts, I know. I guess, canonically, the whole thing could be a ploy for [spoiler]Monika to learn more about emotions and how to manage (and ultimately exploit) them[/spoiler]. Either way, if you played DDLC back in 2018 for the horror, and came away caring more about the characters, it's heartwarming content with some surprisingly touching things to say. Roast me for being soppy; don't care.

The real question is, if you were getting jumped by ten ops in East London, who's gonna back you: Yuri or Natsuki? Natsuki's got the gully attitude, but Yuri's got the zombie knife collection and packs a skeng at all times. These are difficult questions; questions which Dan Salvato never tackles, so I can't rate the game as highly as I'd like. Disappointed.

134268373.review:
Doki Doki Literature Club (the original) is a game that means quite a lot to me. I first played it at a time in my life where I was very lost, and while it’s not like it necessarily “fixed” any of the issues I was having, but it did provide me tons of comfort and something to get obsessed with while I was struggling. Obviously since this title means so much to me, the announcement of an enhanced version of the game known as “Doki Doki Literature Club+” was really really exciting for me. Now that I’ve finally gotten my hands on the title and played it to completion, I feel inclined to share my thoughts on the new content and improvements, not only as a reviewer but as diehard fan of the original release of this title. I will try my best to avoid any focal spoilers for this re-release and the original release, but for the sake of this review having more merit than me simply saying “I liked it”, I will need to spoil a few gameplay aspects.

So lets start off with the obvious question, what exactly is DDLC+? Whilst in the simplest of terms, it is a re-release of the original DDLC with improved graphics that recontextualizes a lot of plot elements, making you view them in a new light, it also features new hidden collectables and a collection of side stories that follow a very wholesome new storyline.

These new side stories that I mentioned also have new music tracks, poems, CGs(A term commonly used to refer to digital paintings in visual novels) and of course new story elements. The side stories are fun and where you’ll be spending the bulk of your time when it comes to new content in this title. The side stories (with a few exceptions) follow different pairings of the four main characters of the game, Sayori, Monika, Natsuki and Yuri. These side stories are full of heartwarming moments (and heavy lesbian undertones). These side stories also happen to provide some context to events like how the literature club actually started, though the canonicity of most of these events is questionable, since some of it conflicts with the established narrative in the main game.

A welcome addition to Doki Doki Literature Club+ is the ability to turn on trigger warnings for some of the darker elements of the experience. DDLC occasionally dives into sensitive subject matter, and this version of the game give the player the ability to turn on trigger warnings before reaching those darker scenes. Personally, I did not use them, since I’m a seasoned veteran with this title, but they’re there for those who want them (I do not suggest using them, but to each their own).

An aspect that I had very mixed feelings about with Doki Doki Literature Club Plus is what I’ll refer to as the “collectable hunting” phase of the game. You see, I’m burdened with glorious purpose, so I felt the need to 100% this title, and while I do think that’s worth doing, a certain aspect of this game can make this completion run be… quite a chore. You see, to unlock the vast majority of the collectable images in this game (Promo art, concept art, etc) you need to grind replaying the main DDLC scenario over and over again, they improved the “skip” feature, which makes this less of a chore than it could’ve been, but near the end of the game I needed 2 more secret poems, and it unironically took me 15+ runs through the game for these random chance poems to spawn. For the most part, I enjoyed the collectables since it makes you explore the main scenario more thoroughly than I ever have before, but the downside is it adds a lot of padding if you’re going for a 100% run like I was. You get a neat reward for 100% the game, so I do suggest doing it, but it can be overly time consuming when I feel like it didn’t need to be that way.

Speaking of the main scenario, while DDLC+ has a significant amount of new content, very little of it affects the main scenario which is where you’ll be spending most of your time still, so I found that to be very disappointing. If you were looking for major changes across the main scenario, I regret to inform you that in that aspect, this game falls short.

I can’t go into to details about this for the sake of spoilers, but I really do think that this release of Doki Doki Literature Club, makes certain aspects of the game such as story immersion much weaker, at least when it comes to the recycled content it has with the original. They made an odd decision with this game that I overall think pays off but the immersion gets axed a bit to do it. I suggest playing the original freeware release of DDLC before playing DDLC+, like I said, I can’t exactly get into why, but just trust me with this, this game should not be the jumping on point for newcomers to the series.

This version of Doki Doki Literature Club has new lore revelations, so if you’re a fan but your on the fence with buying this title, trust me, there’s a lot of new stuff to sink your teeth into, but if you’re a newcomer? Play the freeware version first, and then Plus, I can’t get into why without spoiling things but trust me.

In conclusion, here are my thoughts summarized on DDLC+; Doki Doki Literature Club+ is a phenomenal re-release of the original, it adds a ton of new content and recontextualizes everything in a very fun way. As a fan of the original, I am very impressed with DDLC+ and it is definitely one of my game of the year contenders. With all that being said, I do think the game is lacking for newcomers for numerous reasons, and I would suggest to newcomers to just play the freeware version first. For fans though? This game is a must.

Hats off to you Dan Salvato, you did it again, you mad man!

133291272.review: Wow. Just wow. Where to start? The game sells itself as a wholesome, high-school teen story, revolving four different indistinguishable characters with their own personality and trait that you can easily fall in love with. You start building up your relationship to these characters by writing poems devoted towards each character, where your choice of words will decide which character becomes more friendly and which ones more hostile (Yuri best girl btw). But if that was all of it, you might wonder why this game has so many dark tags attached to it, in connection with all the wholesome stuff? In order for me to avoid spoilers so you can experience this masterpiece yourself first-hand, I am limited to only saying that the story has a dark side to it and everything is not as rainbows and butterflies as the game might fool you to believe. As if that was not enough, this game shares a banger of a soundtrack like almost every other visual novel does. I don't know who they are hiring for these soundtracks, but damn. This game will leave you "hanging" wanting more after playing it and one quick look at the community will just tell you how much this game have affected them and longing for more Doki Doki content that will probably never see the light of day. From personal experience, this game moved me and made me teary-eyed. Really emotional game that awoke buried feelings I had deep inside me I did not know existed. I don't know what it was; the well-written characters, the soundtrack, the story itself or all of these combined together to create a masterpiece? Probably the latter. Hands down, one of the best games I have ever played, and if there is something entertainment is supposed to do, is to make you feel for it or give it a second thought, which most modern movies and games forgot to do and just focuses on feeding you mindless content. So all in all, this is a literal gem when it comes to video games. One of those "must-plays" in my opinion. If anything, this game will always be a fond memory for the rest of my life, which I cannot say about most games I have played. Edit: Adding on the review now after playing the side-stories, I can without a doubt say that this game is an 11/10. I was a bit reluctant at first because of how emotional this game made me after playing through the main story, but then I played through the side-stories, and oh boy. It was 100% worth it. Playing the side-stories fleshed out the characters in addition to the main game and just makes you wish that was how the game actually ended (the ending we never got). I really don't know any other way to put it cause the side-stories kept throwing stuff at you that you always wanted to see but never did. Call if fan-service if you want, but I see it as the complete picture. The main story is just one frame, meanwhile the side-stories are the rest of the painting you don't see. And oh boy, did they outdo themselves with the soundtrack again. They need to stop making these bangers for visual novels man. It should be illegal at this point. All in all, this game made me go from happy, to an emotional wreck and back to being more happy than I was before. My satisfaction is unmeasurable, and words are not enough to describe it. Thank you, Team Salvato, for making such an amazing game with heart and soul put into it!!!

132707592.review:
I've had an interest in visual novels, especially romantic/dating sims, for a few years, and I've had my eye on DDLC for a long time. I just recently played, and now I'm going to express my own thoughts about the game.

First of all, if you're playing DDLC for a romantic plotline and cute interaction with the characters, well, don't expect much and lower your expectations, because I couldn't find what I was looking for in terms of the aforementioned aspects and you'll not find them either. 
Does it mean the game is bad? Well, definitely no! Just don't expect wholly different themes about a game with different purposes.

The game starts in a classic high school setting. You play as a generic high school boy with a childhood "girl friend" named Sayori (not as romantic). She convinces you to join the Literature Club at school, where you meet other characters like Monika, Yuri, and Natsuki. All of the girls have different personalities. Monika is calm and collected, mature; Sayori is energetic and cheerful; Yuri is shy and kind; and Natsuki is blunt but honest. After you get familiar with them, there's a task every day you need to do, and that is writing poems for girls. Here comes the little game about choosing the correct words for each girl and trying to appeal to their tastes. Sometimes there are some choices to be made as well regarding some different situations, and that's the spoiler-free brief about the game. After a few days, things start to get bizarre and uneasy, and that's the point where the real story begins. Really, I can't describe more without spoilers, so I'm going to end it here.

What I'm saying is that DDLC is not a generic romantic VN, unlike its cover, and there are numerous plot twists and surprises. Although the story is well thought out and executed, I wish the game was longer. You should be able to finish it in about 4 hours. The game's saving grace is that it's very replayable, and believe me, you'll find yourself replaying it as soon as you finish it once and trying to come up with alternate endings. However, the choices you made were simply too few and had no effect on the game's scenario. There is a predetermined ending that cannot be avoided no matter what you do, and I know I said before that replayability is excellent, but not because of the choices; you will replay anyway because you will want to learn more about the characters and their backgrounds. One gameplay is insufficient for this, so you'll find yourself writing poems for each girl in order to learn more about them with every new game run.

To conclude, despite its shortcomings, I recommend this to both visual novel fans and newcomers to the genre. This could be your entry point into the world of visual novels!

132077332.review: Doki Doki Literature Club is truly a masterpiece of a game. Stunning illustrations and CGs form an intense visual novel, with an even deeper story that cannot be seen at first glance. (Seriously, the ACTUAL story behind this game is heavy). What may be disguised as an innocent dating sim at first turns into something much more twisted, and leads the player through the minds of 4 different characters. The game forces you to think outside the box (and outside the game itself). Doki Doki Literature Club Plus adds much more depth to each individual character, and makes you feel connected to the characters even more. I think it is definitely worth buying if you want to experience different backstories and extra content, but even more importantly, it gives depth to the characters that is not as much in the original base game, enabling you to empathise with the different girls and their different values, traits, and personal problems. Along with these side stories, DDLC plus is filled with beautiful illustrations, a soundtrack which can be customised, and much more lore (if you are into the theory side, lore-wise.) Overall, I would say that Doki Doki Literature Club Plus is one of my favourite Visual Novels out there, if not one of my favourite games in general. I would absolutely recommend this game to visual novel fans, and anyone who isn't faint at heart and loves a good psychological horror game.

Haber, honestamente no soy digamos un fan del género de novelas visuales, solo DDLC y Katawa Shoujo serian los únicos de este género que jugaría (Steins gate no porque ya me vi su anime [tremenda obra maestra]), yo jugué este titulo debido a su gran popularidad debido a que se le conocía por tener momentos espeluznantes o escenas fuertes, entonces decidí probarlo porque era gratis y que puedo decir, me encantó, sus personajes, historia y forma original de los eventos que si llega a inquietar un poco fueron bastante buenos, pues el simple hecho de que uno de los personajes sabe que esta dentro de un videojuego y viendo como ella misma toma el control de el y se deshace de las demás chicas para que se quede sola con nosotros es algo que no se ve todos los días en una novela visual, lo que hace Doki doki literature club mas que un juego, fue mas una experiencia, que ya sea buena o inquietante como sea que la percibiste todos coincidimos en que el final nos deja un vació a todos nosotros después de todo lo que experimentamos, y que al final no podemos cambiarlos.......o bueno, podemos mejorarlo, pero sigue sin ser suficiente.

Bien, ahora esta versión Plus se puede interpretar como una versión extendida del titulo, si bien la historia principal sigue igual, tenemos como añadido nuevas historias paralelas que nos cuenta como fue la llegada de cada una de las integrantes del club y como se forjo su relación y que puedo decir, fue hermoso verlo; ademas de esto y añadir cosas bonus como ver las imágenes, fondos, secretos, etc; también este titulo expandió el lore de este titulo aun mas dándonos mas muestra de que esto es mas que una novela visual de 4 chicas formando un club de literatura.

Y acerca de las 4 chicas, son pocas, pero son mas que suficientes e irreemplazables, tenemos a:

 Sayori: nuestra amiga de la infancia que su mayor característica es su gran optimismo, dicho optimismo con el fin de ocultar su depresión y evitar que las personas se preocupen por ella.

Natsuki: una pequeña chica con alto carácter malhumorado pero es bastante amante del manga que le a servido para refugiarse y tener un sustento de alivio ante sus traumas debido a los abusos de su propio padre.

Yuri: una chica que a primera vista luce tímida e introvertida pero en el fondo es una amante de la literatura del genero horror/gore generándole un gusto obsesivo por este tipo de cosas, cosa que ha hecho que no a podido conseguir ninguna amiga antes debido a sus extravagantes gustos (ademas de su fácil obsesión hacia cualquier cosa).

Monika: una "chica" talentosa que formó un club de literatura para crear un lugar donde todos puedan sentirse cómodos, siendo esta decisión su mayor error.

Si te preguntas si vale la pena comprar este titulo, pues te diré deque si eres fan o no igualmente es un completo si, ya que este titulo es bastante completo (pasárselo al 100% toma un chingo de tiempo) y no te decepcionará, y si eres fan con mayor razón compratelo ya que lo sentirás mas como un regalo que un juego solamente, honestamente un juego que te da una experiencia que se lo recomiendo a todos; no temas en probar este titulo ya que hey, este es solo un juego acerca de un club de literatura, verdad?

130782698.review:
Very nice surprise! Having now played DDLC+ instead of getting sleep I can say I have no regrets. DDLC+ is a perfect example of the psychological horror genre and it truly is a new way to feel fear. However, this isn’t just a horror game and because of its incredible concept I’ll have a hard time forgetting it. I’ve replayed it multiple times and I’ve fallen in love with the incredible design of Doki Doki Literature Club! 

The visual novel and dating side of DDLC+ is perfectly crafted and could easily be taken as a stand alone game. Each of the girls have colorful personalities and the interactions are well thought out. The 6 new side stories you get with DDLC+ do a great job at building the relationships between the girls while going in depth about the forming of the literature club. I also loved how rereading not only the poems but also the characters' dialogue reveals little hints as to what the true nature of the story is. 

The horror side of this game is really what steals the show and it’s a must try. The way this game scares you is by slowly making you notice that things are off and by giving you hints of what’s hidden beneath the cracks. The growing unease you have while playing the game is chilling and the fear you feel isn’t something that you can see and completely grasp. This is what makes DDLC’s horror absolutely terrifying because it builds up inside you and gets into your head.

This version of the game does lose some of its immersion because you don’t get to interact with the real game files. However, DDLC+ does make it easy to quickly revisit scenes and poems from the game without having to play through it again and again. I found the virtual desktop rather handy and I spent a good amount of time listening to this game's outstanding OST while looking at sketches, poems, and CGs offered in the Plus version. So for convenience and especially for the side stories I seriously recommend DDLC+!

I’m not writing a 5 paragraph essay so I’ll leave it at that but if you are hesitating on buying DDLC+ I would definitely recommend you give it a shot. I can’t think of any other game that portrays psychological horror as good as DDLC does while also blending in a cute visual novel and I’m sure you’ll love this masterfully designed game! Just be ready to replay the game a few times if you're looking to unlock all the content and see all the possibilities. I hope everyone can have as good of an experience with this game as I did and remember to spend time with Monika! 



















Just Monika…

129813306.review:
Doki Doki Literature Club Plus was released in 2021 as a console supported re-release of the game ‘Doki Doki Literature Club’ originally released in 2017. (This review will be a continuation of my last review on DDLC.)

At first, when I purchased this game I thought it lacked content. It wasn't until I dug deeper into the array of additional easter eggs and images that I was proved wrong. If you are a fan of the first game and want to dig deeper into the lore then I would suggest you play this game.

The game is now accessed through a simulated faux-desktop. At your desktop you have a number of options: files, wallpapers, mail, side stories, pictures and music. All of which are unlockable from playing the base game.

The aim is for the player to gain as much ‘data’ as possible. By collecting all the data you will obtain all achievements. Along the way you unlock images, wallpapers and also the ‘Side Stories’ ; these are the most noticeable new element added to the game. The side stories reveal more about each of the four girls present in DDLC. There is a disclaimer however that the side stories are“not canon to the main story”. 

The email function explains the purpose of the game. We find out there is another name for the base game, which is VM1. We also learn that there is a VM2. If you thought VM1 had dark themes then VM2 will blow your mind. We learn that in VM1 the game creators have given Monika a heightened conscience to see how it affects the game and see how she reacts. This results in her deleting Sayori, Natsuki and Yuri out of jealousy. When you reset the game through the files function it says ‘Monitor_Kernal_Access] ’ which is how Monika got her name. Moni from ‘Monitor’ and the ka from ‘Kernel Access’ Monika. This also explains why her name is the only name in the game that doesn't sound japanese. 

An email titled ‘Issues caused by unprotected memory’ states that “My best guess is that memory being freed from VM2 isn't getting zeroed out, which technically gives VM1 access to it”. This means something horrific when you look deeper into the lore of VM2. Monika has memories of VM2 while being present in VM1. We get a picture that VM2 is some sort of cult-like reality where people are experimented on to find their “third eye potential”. People are theorizing that Sayori, Natsuki and Yuri are the ones being experimented on and Monika is a nurse in this reality, in VM2. Also it seems likely she will be called ‘Marla’ here as the email about VM2 aka ‘Project Libitina’ reads “Monitor Adjacent Runtime-Level Access” 

This would explain why monika asks for our help. At one point in the game she ends her poem with “delete her” she is making this in reference to Yuri who is becoming evermore unhinged by this point in the game. Then a box appears saying “please help me.” and we have no choice but to click ‘ok’. This could be in reference to many things but after the poem asking us for help with deleting Yuri I feel that's what it is referencing. 

I mentioned before why she might be deleting these characters files. I said she might be jealous, however with this new found information about VM2 it could change Monika’s ulterior motives entirely. Motives could be far removed from any jealous attack that the last game has given Monika a reputation for. We know that Monika is very smart and this is shown throughout the game; she writes in a mature way, she changes the game files of the game, and it is even theorized that Monika has found a way out of the game. We know she is able to access memories from VM2 and that could very well be why she wants these character files gone because she doesn't want to see any more harm coming to these three individuals, her friends. There is an email that reads “Monika’s meddling is less clumsy than we think” all I can say is that I don't think anyone should underestimate Monika. 

Monika knows not to speak about VM2 because in the third chapter of the game she begins to speak about the book Yuri was reading but then stops herself, as she knows better than talking about the book with us, as it is about the world of VM2. This reaffirms how clever she is. How she knows she is being watched. This also impacted her attitude when Yuri and Sayori died because she doesn't want the game makers to suspect anything. She wants them to believe she wants attention from us the player, Insead of what she really feels, that she doesn't want her friends to be experimented on. 

This game breathes new life and lore to a game that was released 4 years prior. I highly recommend it! 
 { Thanks for listening } <3

129367113.review:
You may not like it, but this is still one of the most important VNs ever made.

Yes, obviously in the greater cultural context of visual novels, there are better ones with higher production quality, tighter stories, better scares, blah, blah, blah. But there's so many people that KNOW what visual novels are BECAUSE of this game. That is a step in the right direction for the medium as a whole if it ever hopes to expand to global relevance. This game has good ideas and a fun gameplay loop that hooked people for a reason. Now it's other aspiring VNs jobs to learn from DDLCs successes and mistakes to make even better games.

And Sayori's monologue about depression is still so real. The game is worth it for that three minute period alone, regardless of everything else.

Chalking this up to streamer bait and nothing more is like throwing sand in your own eyes if you give a damn about VNs at all. This game is worth studying. It's worth playing. And it's probably better than anything you've written yourself soooooooooooo, yeah.

128501029.review:
A classic anime visual novel that excels at genre bending,  psychological horror, 4th wall breaking, self-awareness, and game design. Worth experiencing blind, if possible. The Story and Characters are not ground-breaking, but definitely tug on your heartstrings, especially the new Side Stories included in this version exclusively. Soundtrack is fantastic to listen to and really sets the tone for each scene. Visuals are quite impressive for a visual novel. 

The game isn't perfect though. There isn't much gameplay aside from a poem minigame, choosing which girl to follow, and progressing the main story. The themes can get quite dark in the latter half of the game and your emotional boundaries will be tested during this portion of the game. It is not for the faint of heart. Some Easter eggs/ secrets/events are hidden in pretty obscure places and can be easily missed by first-time players. The game's meta elements are not as well hidden in this game as the original. At this point, I'm kind of nitpicking.

If you haven't experienced this game yet and are okay with disturbing content, then give this game a go.

7.5 / 10

128331799.review:
As the title says, this is DDLC plus a few extra things. If you are impatient and can't play a game more than once, this isn't for you since you have to play it multiple times to get all the extra side stories. If you want the standard DDLC experience, though, the main game is entirely free. I also do recommend you play the original before deciding to buy this one, as you play the main game multiple times to get more content in this version. 

My honest reaction to that information:

I love DDLC+, if there's any new reason to play through DDLC again, this is definitely one of them. I remember being oblivious to the deep stuff behind it and thinking it was one of those one-off VNs meant to attract an audience to get them to buy the other games. Oh boy, was I wrong. This game probably sparked my interest in storytelling beyond the more traditional medians. This game goes beyond how a game can tell a story and lore to the point that you literally go through the game's files to progress it. (Sidenote this particular one has you enter into a fake PC so you don't actually mess with the real files. Check out the original one for more of that stuff.) (Side-sidenote I'll go more into detail about the main game when I write my review on the original one (IF I write one, anyways lol))

The real meat of this game is the side stories, though. I loved the side stories, even though I'm not a huge characters guy anymore. Each one of the stories takes two of the main characters and builds their relationship with each other while also going into depth upon the founding of the literature club. The amount of references they make to the main game is a very nice touch because the side stories (supposedly) take place before the main game which ties together the characters for when the main game takes place.

If you've played DDLC a couple times and are willing to do it all over again to go even deeper, this game is definitely worth the investment.

Might remove this review later if I wake up one day and cringe at what I wrote here.

Recomendado

127194942.review:
Frankly, in my opinion, one of the best games to date. - 10/10

spoilers - probably

While it disguises itself as a  dating game, and maybe it is in act one, it has much more to offer.
I like horror, this game has it, but I think the horror aspect brings it up and back down again.. 
Honestly, the story was so good the horror made me more mad that all the characters had such a sad ending.

Some may have severe depression or anxiety or a bad home life, this game covers these in a much more exciting and serious way than those mental health ads on YouTube. 

I do think the addition of side stories in the plus version helps quench my thirst for a more fulfilling story and it really does reveal a lot about the characters, it still doesn't cover everything I'd like.

Dan Salvato put in a lot of work into the story telling, and looking at the base game more than the average player can really put a lot into perspective, as I've said before, it has a lot of mental health related topics and Natsuki is obviously bullied and made fun of by everyone around her and she as a character I think was made to symbolise the bullies at Dan's school when he was younger.

He liked Nintendo games but the other kids were more into COD etc.

Well, enough ranting, I'll save that for a YouTube video

10/10

125730976.review:
This is an excellent game, and the experience will stay with you long after you finish playing it.
It manages to be a lot a lot of things at once - it’s a parody of the visual novel/dating sim genre, while still having some genuinely heartwarming story in its own right. It’s an unsettling psychological horror experience, but is still full of bittersweet moments and interesting insights about life and literature. The pace and subtle foreshadowing in the story is extremely well executed, with lots of details to catch that warrant multiple play-throughs. 

If you like a game that surprises you, rips out your heart and stomps into the ground, and leaves you with a lingering existential dread that follows long after you finish the game - but somehow is so captivating you still want to play again and again - then this is for you. 

Not necessarily a game for everyone, but there’s nothing else out there quite like it. 10/10
